sa35.43-45:1.2: One time, the Buddha stayed at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa35.43-45:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa35.43-45:2.2: “What is it that exists, that arises, that ties, that’s an attachment, and that’s viewed as self and causes sentient beings to create such views and such statements?
sa35.43-45:2.3: ‘There’s no power, no effort, and no power and effort.
sa35.43-45:2.4: There are no men who are skillful, no men who are diligent, and no men who are skillful and diligent.
sa35.43-45:2.5: There’s nothing self-made, nothing made by others, and nothing made by self and others.
sa35.43-45:2.6: All people, all sentient beings, and all spirits lack skill, lack power, lack force, lack effort, and lack capability.
sa35.43-45:2.7: Their certain lot is continuity, change, and the experience of the six destinies of pleasure and pain.’”
sa35.43-45:3.1: The monks said to the Buddha,
sa35.43-45:3.2: “The Bhagavān is the Dharma root, the Dharma eye, and the Dharma refuge …”
sa35.43-45:3.3: *It’s thus explained in detail and in the sequence of the three sutras (35.7-9) above.*
